Hi, I'm having some doubts in doing my research and was hoping that I
could=
 seek some help here.

Basically, I have two algorithms that I want to comp=
are (both use NEAT
btw), but have to first choose the parameter values for =
each
algorithm. I suppose that to have a fair comparison, each algorithm
sh=
ould be tested with different parameter settings to determine its
ideal set=
ting. My question is, how comprehensive should it be? (eg.
for 1 variable, =
should we test 10 different values? should we have 10
trials for each run?)=
 This has become my concern because I don't want
to waste too much time in =
finding the right parameters.

I am mostly concerned with finding the appro=
priate mutation
probabilities (mut add link, mut add node, mut link weight,=
 mut power).

I looked through some papers on how they chose their paramete=
rs when
comparing, and noticed that researchers usually say that the settin=
gs
are found experimentally, without mention of how comprehensive it is.
Al=
so, most don't show experimental statistics of these parameter
testing. Is =
it because such thing is trivial? 

I appreciate your answers. Thanks!
